title: Fix browserify reference.
body: Otherwise, browserify fails with an error.  Also, we should push a new version to NPM!

title: Support AMD/RequireJS.
body: When d3.js is loaded, it now prefers the AMD define function or module.exports if available; the global `d3` is only set if neither of these are available. A side benefit of this change is that browserify, bower and component can now load the D3 library directly rather than needing a custom definition.

title: Add d3.geo.path.distance.
body:
Unfortunately, d3.geo.path.length is unavailable since d3.geo.path() returns a function, for which the "length" property cannot be overridden.

Fixes #1556.

title: Use browserified index.js for bower
body:
I might be completely mistaken since I still struggle with definitions and combinations of `npm`, `bower`, `component` and all the other things in frontend JavaScript. However, when using `d3` with `bower`, only an empty object is returned from a `require("d3")` and indeed, there is only a `return d3` in `d3.js` instead of Node-style `module.exports = d3`. The latter is done with `index-browserify.js` and it seems logical to me to use that for `bower`.

(I've just noticed that I also have to update `bin/bower`, will do so immediately and update the pull request)

title: Make jsdom an optional dependency
body: The rationale is that many people use NPM to install dependencies for browser apps (not Node ones), and `jsdom` is a problematic dependency because it requires Xcode instead of just command-line-tools on OS X.

title: Play nicer with browserify
body:
The existing browserify package has the behavior that `require('d3')` wipes out any preexisting `d3` global. This is problematic if you want to use D3 internally in a package but allow that package to be consumed in projects that themselves might use D3 (and perhaps a different version, or a custom smash build).

Can we modify `start.js` and `end.js` to conditionally check for a node/browserify environment and not create a global? Something like this, but I haven't considered all of the ramifications (and this breaks the tests).

title: Replaced division with multiplication
body: This is actually [twice as fast](http://jsperf.com/multiply-division/2).

title: Fixes nice() for sub-second scales
body:
When the interval between ticks would be measured in milliseconds, calling `nice()` fails with the following trace:

```
Uncaught TypeError: Object #<Object> has no method 'floor' d3.v3.js:9186
scale.domain.skip.floor d3.v3.js:9186
d3_scale_nice d3.v3.js:6893
scale.nice d3.v3.js:9184
...
```

The `Object` is `d3_time_scaleMilliseconds`, which does lack `floor` and `ceil`.

This PR adds a test to catch this failure, and it adds `floor` and `ceil` to `d3_time_scaleMilliseconds`, which fixes the issue.

title: Fix #1664 - empty classed string.
body: The regex used for split was returning [""] for the input "", rather than [].

title: Use `inDelta` not `equals` for double comparisons in polygon area test
body:
Fixes this:

```
    area Polygon
      ✗ lune
        » expected 3.141592653589793,
        got  3.1415926535897927 (==) // area-test.js:50
  ✗ Broken » 2546 honored ∙ 1 broken (9.349s)
  npm ERR! Test failed.  See above for more details.
npm ERR! not ok code 0
```

title: Add d3.random.bates; fix d3.random.irwinHall.
body: Fixes #1647. What was previously classified as an Irwin–Hall distribution was in fact a Bates distribution. The irwinHall implementation is fixed, and a new bates implementation is added.

title: Arbitrary transverse projections.
body:
Fixes #1157. I’m not sure I implemented this correctly, however. I tested it using http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/5126418/ and http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/4695821/ and it seems to work well, but the tests are broken. I’m not certain I’m accounting for the projection’s translate and center correctly when undoing the rotation after projection.

Also, this is strictly incompatible in terms of d3.geo.transverseMercator.raw, since the transverse mercator is now a special-case of the Mercator projection. But I suspect that’s probably okay.

Alternatively, we could keep the special raw transverse Mercator implementation, but then we’d need to implement equatorial cutting (?) rather than antimeridian cutting.

It would also be good to test the performance of this approach vs. the previous one.

title: Allow multiple locales.
body:
Fixes #750. Code that requires localization is now within a closure that has access to locale-specific strings.

To minimize the degree of isolation required, d3.scale.linear (and other quantitative scales, including d3.time.scale) still default to the en-US locale. However, you can create your own localized formats using locale.numberFormat and locale.timeFormat.

(It would be possible to move these other classes to within d3.locale as well, but that would mean anything that depends on d3.scale.linear would also need to be moved within d3.locale, such as d3.svg.axis. I think it’s cleaner to leave them using a default locale rather and have people localize the formats explicitly, rather than classes that localize anything downstream; you can always reassign d3.format to a different locale if you want to change the default.)

Also introduces locale.timeFormat.multi which can be used to create a [multi-scale time format](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/4149176), and improves currency formatting by allowing the currency symbol to appear after the numeric value.

title: I18n (internationalization and localization) at runtime
body:
Dear Mike Bostock,
out of the box D3.js is shipped with english text labels for months and week names.
Setting axis-date-format is already possible and I can differ the format depending on the language.
I like to add the option to do so for labels, too.
In my WebApp users can select their favourite language.
But I do not like to store multiple D3 files, differing only at a few rows of string definitions.
With this patch, you could overwrite the labels to any language you like.
 As far as I know, renaming this strings later does not produce side effects, because calculations e. g. european and us calendar weeks are already done.

1) import d3.js
2) set localised strings like
switch ( locale ) {
            case 'de':
                d3.time.setLocalizedStrings( MyLocalizations.localeStrings.de.dayNames,
                        MyLocalizations.localeStrings.de.dayNamesShort,
                        MyLocalizations.localeStrings.de.monthNames,
                        MyLocalizations.localeStrings.de.monthNamesShort );
                // localizeD3DateFormat: use german presets
                break;
            case 'fr':
                d3.time.setLocalizedStrings( MyLocalizations.localeStrings.fr.dayNames,
                        MyLocalizations.localeStrings.fr.dayNamesShort,
                        MyLocalizations.localeStrings.fr.monthNames,
                        MyLocalizations.localeStrings.fr.monthNamesShort );
                break;
            case 'en': ...........
3) start using d3

So it is possible to rewrite the labels to any language you like without shipping multiple files of almost the same content.
Is there a better way to do so?
What is your oppinion?

Kind regards,
Daniel Suess from Berlin

title: include d3 shim config for jspm
body: This was left out of the previous pull request unfortunately.

title: Implement .size(), .empty() for d3.{set,map}
body: closes #1648.

title: d3.random tests (see issue #539)
body:
#539 has been around for 2 years. It's about time someone got it done.

(closes #539  )

title: Faster and cleaner convex hull
body:
The current convex hull algorithm is not very good. I rewrote it to make it faster, cleaner and shorter. The old one was:
- Slow -- calculated 'real' angles using atan2 instead of taking advantage of fast implicit angle comparisons via cross product. This algorithm does not sort by angle at all (sorts by coordinates instead, which is much faster).
- Overly verbose and confusing. This one is cleaner and shorter.
- It also had a bug related to custom accessors.

Please ignore the strange commit logs, I got a bit confused.

title: Don’t output points at exactly -180° when clipping.
body:
Previously, we were generating points along the antimeridian at λ=±180°
when clipping.  Strictly speaking, on a sphere, -180° is the same
longitude as +180°.  Internally, we can distinguish these “coincident”
points and preserve the longitude’s sign when converting to and from
Cartesian coordinates by assuming that atan2(sin(±π), x<0)=±π.

Up until now, this has worked, probably due to floating point roundoff
in Math.PI meaning that abs(λ) < π, and hence sin(±Math.PI) is a very
small non-zero number, effectively preserving the sign of the longitude.

It seems Chrome Canary has added some minor approximations, which
improve performance but bring to light our reliance on this behaviour,
since sin(+Math.PI) = sin(-Math.PI) = +0.  Strictly speaking, I think
Chrome should return -0 for sin(-Math.PI), but we probably shouldn’t
rely on it, as it’s not in ECMAScript.

I had already made a minor modification to avoid generating these
“coincident” points in the clip-polygon branch.  I decided longitudes
should be in the range [-180°, +180°), and thus points were output with
longitudes -π and π - ε.  This was required to fix various issues with
handling of coincident points elsewhere.

In Chrome, this modification doesn’t actually fix the problem, because
atan2(sin(-π), x)=π where x<0, so λ=-180° becomes λ=+180° when
resampling.  Instead, the range (-180, +180°] does in fact fix the
issue, using λ=ε-π and λ=π.  As I mentioned above, it would be nice if
Chrome’s implementation gave atan2(sin(-Math.PI), x<0)=-Math.PI.

For good measure, I’ve enforced this in d3.geo.rotation too, ensuring
that input points with λ<ε-π become λ=+π.

We could go further and output points at abs(λ)=π-ε, but it seems
unnecessary as the above already preserves the longitude’s sign.

Note: I haven’t updated any tests for this change.

Fixes #1635.

title: Avoid flipping longitude near ±π.
body: When computing the midpoint between two points both at longitude -π, there was a chance that atan2 would return +π rather than -π. Now, we check whether the points to interpolate lie (approximately) on a meridian; if they do, we can approximate by using linear interpolation of longitude rather than atan2. This fixes #1635 which was caused by new trig implementations in Chrome Canary.

title: add jspm package.json config
body:
With this configuration in the package.json, it will allow d3 to be loaded through jspm as easily as:

http://jsbin.com/uVAxOvah/2/edit

Including minification with source maps.

It would be great to have this included if possible. Any questions just ask.

title: [CI] Testing node versions up to 10.22.
body: Included all interim versions.

title: Fix transform for ordinal→quantitative scales.
body:
Previously, invalid transform attributes were being set for an
ordinal→quantitative scale transition, because entering ticks were
undefined in the old (ordinal) scale, and exiting ticks were undefined
in the new (quantitative) scale.

Fixes #1620.

title: Add children(), ancestor() and parent() methods to d3.selection
Filter function did not get parent group index
body:
When filtering a selection/transition, the callback function was not getting the second group index. I am unable to build/test since npmjs is currently down, but it seems pretty apparent this is the fix.

Note that looking for other instances of this with e.g. `grep '\bi)' -R src/selection src/transition` it appears the transition tween functions are also missing this (and more difficultly so, since it looks like their third parameter is already used for something else) and perhaps the data bind (although AFAICT this third parameter may not be appropriate in that context anyway).

title: Set context of callback to data, up one level
